title: School Notes: Hartford High freshman chosen to represent Windsor County in Vt. Youth Council
content:
Secondary accomplishments

Hartford High School freshman Ezra Tane will represent Windsor County at the Vermont State Youth Council for the next three years. The council, which includes 28 members from around the state, gives advice to the governor and Legislature about topics that affect young people in the state.

Lebanon High School’s French Honor Society chapter has been named a Bronze Level sponsor by the American Association of Teachers of French.

Post-secondary graduations

Nolan Gantrish, of Hanover, earned a bachelor’s degree in health and human kinetics from Ohio Wesleyan University in Delaware, Ohio, this summer.

Post-secondary honors

The following Upper Valley residents made the student honors list at the Community College of Vermont for the summer 2025 semester: Kayla Ainsworth, Corinth;
Jeremy Goodridge, Corinth; Mercedes Reaugh, Hartland; Kaitlyn Saucier, Hartland; Grace Stockwell, Lebanon; Ruth Nelson, Newbury, Vt.; Lomond Richardson, Newbury, Vt.; Megan Roberts, Norwich; Moriah Wojciechowski, Quechee; Sydney Deitrick, South Royalton; Andrew Ruddell, South Royalton; Madisyn D’Amico, White River Junction; and Naomi Ellison, White River Junction.

Kathryn Rohrbach, of Weathersfield, and Joshua Hamel, of White River Junction, made the president’s list at the Community College of Vermont for the summer 2025 semester.

Monica Austin, of West Fairlee, made the dean’s list at the Community College of Vermont for the summer 2025 semester.

Terence Sharp, of Lebanon, and Owen Taylor, of Newport, made the dean’s list at the University of Maryland Global Campus in Adelphi, Maryland, for the summer 2025 semester.

Email academic accomplishments to schoolnotes@vnews.com.

The post School Notes: Hartford High freshman chosen to represent Windsor County in Vt. Youth Council appeared first on Valley News.

tags: American Association of Teachers of French
v1_analysis.one_sentence_summary: Hartford High freshman Ezra Tane selected for Vermont State Youth Council while numerous Upper Valley students earn academic honors at various institutions.
v1_analysis.enhanced_summary:
Hartford High School freshman Ezra Tane has been selected to represent Windsor County on the Vermont State Youth Council for a three-year term, joining 27 other young people from across the state who advise the governor and Legislature on youth-related issues. The announcement was part of the Valley News' regular School Notes roundup, which also recognized Lebanon High School's French Honor Society chapter as a Bronze Level sponsor by the American Association of Teachers of French, and honored numerous Upper Valley students who made academic honors lists at Community College of Vermont and other institutions during the summer 2025 semester.

This positive education story (sentiment: 0.8) stands notably above the week's average sentiment of 0.35 for education topics, contrasting sharply with recent coverage focused on legal challenges and policy disputes in the region. While the Valley News has published five education-related articles this week, most have centered on contentious issues including a lawsuit over New Hampshire's loitering law affecting unhoused people, FAFSA complications, and a federal judge's decision to block New Hampshire's DEI ban in most school districts. Tane's appointment represents a more traditional civic engagement story, highlighting youth participation in Vermont's democratic processes through an established state council structure.

The selection matters as it gives Windsor County's young residents direct input into state-level policy discussions affecting their peers for the next three years. The Vermont State Youth Council serves as an official advisory body, providing lawmakers and the governor with perspectives from constituents who typically have limited formal influence over legislation despite being directly impacted by decisions on education, mental health, and youth services. As education policy continues to generate controversy across the Upper Valley—evidenced by ongoing legal battles over DEI restrictions and equity issues—Tane's role offers a constructive channel for youth voices in Vermont's policy debates.
